author: charliegj94
title: Adult son and lack of help from Drug and Alcohol Single Point of Access Rhondda (Barod)
body:
My son was referred to DASPA over two months ago. His worker contacted him and visited him one or two weeks later. This is the first time my son has actively tried to engage with drug services for his cannabis dependency and it was promising that he asked for the help. His specialist therapist informed us that if he engages with the key worker then there is a good chance of gaining health funding to access longer term rehab. For the first time in a long time my son had hope.  
However, fast forward a month or so and he has been let down so often by his keyworker not turning up to appointments, not phoning when they said they were going to phone, and the process of trying to chase them up, that he feels resigned that there is no help for him.  
I can’t express enough how upsetting it is for a young adult to have this hope taken away from him.  
Last time we spoke to DASPA the key worker suggested that they haven't been able to get hold of my son, that the call had gone straight to voicemail. However this has not happened to anyone who has tried to phone him. Furthermore, the key worker had his dad and my number. I tried phoning and texting but I received no response.  
I am shocked and appalled that vulnerable people are left feeling helpless by the organisations who are supposed to be there to help them. I want something done about this so it doesn’t happen to anyone else but I cannot find information on their website about who to complain to.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Maccers28
title: They kept me alive
body:
I just want to put in writing my thanks and gratitude to the staff at Royal Victoria Hospital & Lagan Valley Hospital.  
I had 2 heart attacks, actually died in theatre for 8 mins, woke up in ICU wired up to a life support machine for a week, but the team at RVH were excellent.  
They kept me alive and that is something I will always be thankful for. Upon discharge I was referred to LVH for cardiac rehab and the team there are fantastic. Luna who runs the show is a diamond, total professional in her trade and lovely with it.  
I have nothing but praise for the aftercare I have received since my heart attacks. The NHS deserve all the credit they get.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust
Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: LisaMcA
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Grateful for acute care at home
body:
Letter received from family member of female patient from Derry / Londonderry area.  
Dear Dr Todd,  
My sister, brother and myself are most grateful to you and the Acute Care at Home team for the excellent care and support offered recently to my sister in Culmore Manor Nursing Home.  
Obviously, the care provided is team-based and any team member I met was most welcoming and supportive.  
We are well aware of the reality of the situation but take great comfort from knowing that you have offered our sister similar care in the future if required, so avoiding a return to hospital.  
Words of gratitude simply do not adequately express our appreciation to you and the team for all you have done.  
Just know that, as a family, we are deeply appreciative of your efforts.  
Please express out thanks to all the members of the team.  
Yours sincerely

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Lindsay48
title: Understanding and caring team at endoscopy
body:
Went to lagan valley hospital a few days ago.  
From the first nurse that seen me, then the consultant / Endoscopist Dr Hand and nurse Jetherton and Bindu, I could not thank them enough. They were wonderful, very understanding and very caring and got me through it so thanks to the first nurse that called me to the last nurse to show me the way out.  
Yous are all fantastic and very professional. Thanks!

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Diane62
title: They talked me through the procedure
body:
Had minor oral surgery (2 biopsies) and the staff couldn’t have been nicer.  
Not the most pleasant procedure but they talked me through it and reassured me. During the op they regularly checked that I was okay.  
After, they talked me through what to expect and what to do. Lovely staff.

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Daisy ward is out of this world
body:
Accident and emergency was quite quick, do not have much to say about it. The staff were lovely, the ones I did have an interaction with.  
Daisy ward is out of this world, the place is so child friendly and the way they look after the children is outstanding. The level of care is brilliant and they cannot do enough for you.  
The staff are fabulous, they are always close by and checking in to make sure everything is okay. There is no complaints or improvements I can see.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Innes1995C
title: This service has been second to none
body:
I had to have a procedure done a couple of months back. I live in the highlands of Scotland and contacted Aberdeen sexual health, by passing a sexual health clinic closer to home for many negative reasons.  
I well and truly cannot speak higher of the service I got in Aberdeen, every single person. Nurses and receptionist have been outstandingly amazing to talk to, phone calls back very fast. Being there for advice. Never once did they make me second guess my thoughts and have been there to support me even months after.  
They’re incredible each and every one of them. To the point I got emotional on the phone, after how nice the nurse was to me. Yes I had to travel and stay with my sister in Aberdeen for a short period but it was well and truly worth it.  
The service I’ve received in Aberdeen Health village is second to none. I will be travelling down to get a coil fitted, over 360 miles. That’s because of how everyone in the health village has made me feel! Seriously incredible! Thanks so much ladies xxxxxxxx

readBy.name: Aberdeen City Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Saintfield
title: Excellent and caring unit
body:
I would like to thank all the staff for the excellent care and attention I have received in this unit over several years.  
I particularly want to thank Doctor Moore and nurse Amanda yesterday for arranging my blood test at short notice. The way in which the doctors and nurses organise the unit and have such a caring attitude is exemplary.  
Thank you all.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: The staff are phenomenal
body:
Came into accident and emergency and we were seen somewhat quickly. The experience was okay in there. It seems to move quicker if it’s a child which I could not complain about. They kept me in the loop of what was happening and what their plan was going forward.  
The staff were good and very helpful. They were all very nice down there.  
Daisy ward is a complete contrast to the whole hospital it is outstanding. I do not have any complaints about up here it is all great.  
The staff are phenomenal they are always here when you need them and their standard of care is brilliant.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Boymum93
title: Antrim area scubu
body:
I had my son eight weeks early in 2020. When my son was being cared for in the NICU everything was great and the nurses were wonderful. I felt that they really understood the trauma i had been through, that they understood my worries and fears for my son and that they respected my role as his mother and primary caregiver. I was included in every aspect of his care, was informed of all the details of his treatment and asked for my consent and input.  
When my son moved to the scbu there was a dramatic and traumatic change in the treatment I received. I overheard members of the nursing team talking in derogatory terms about some of the mothers with babies in the unit. I witnessed tiny babies being left to cry and even heard one nurse openly slating the concept of kangaroo care. All the guidance I read both in preparation for becoming a mother and once my son was born recommended this type of care as the gold standard. I was aware that all babies but in particular premature babies benefit immensely from as much skin to skin contact as possible and that it is impossible to "spoil" a baby by holding them too much. This staff member suggested that if I continued kangaroo care my son would be clingy and spoilt. To hear this from a professional was extremely confusing for me especially as a new first time mother trying my best to bond with and nurture my child. I was discouraged from breastfeeding my child on demand by the same staff member, and I was advised to leave my child in his incubator. Again this was contrary to all the research I had done in advance regarding breastfeeding. This incident completely broke me. I started having panic attacks and no longer felt welcome in the SCBU. I had plans to sit with my son during the night but was told to leave and that they don't let parents stay overnight. However, I witnessed many other parents staying overnight. I felt like because I was clearly a single parent I was treated differently from other two parent families.  
I told another SCBU staff member about the incident and they asked if they could speak to a senior member of staff about it and I agreed. Unfortunately, this did not help. This staff member spoke to me and said that it was the same as if someone was raped and came forward years later to report it - that not much is going to be done about it. Using a sexual assault analogy seemed incredibly inappropriate to me and the fact that my real and legitimate concerns were dismissed so cruelly was very upsetting.  
The time my son had left in the SCBU was absolute torture with there was little to no discussion with me about discharge plans for my son. I felt every day that there was no end date in sight. When I did manage to get some discussion about a possible discharge plan for my son (at my insistence) I was told that there was no problem, and that I could stay at the weekend to establish breastfeeding. This was after I pushed the issue quite forcefully (or as forcefully as I could manage given that I was exhausted, distressed, had just been through major surgery and was very concerned about treatment I and my child were receiving). I was incredibly confused and concerned by the fact that I alone, and not the medical professionals, was left to consider a plan for my son's discharge. I was then told I might not get to stay because another mother might be staying in the room. Staff offered no explanation as to why the other mother was being prioritised nor did they offer an alternative plan to allow me to care for my son.  
I really feel that the treatment we received in the SCBU was substantially below standard and even now, two years later, I find it difficult to reflect on that time without becoming very upset.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: defenderqd35
title: Giving birth in Antrim during covid
body:
I was induced at 40w 1 day due to a large baby, back in March 2020. When I was induced I was told my partner would be allowed in. Then the rules changed that day but they would let him stay as he was already in.  
However when my waters broke and I was in full established labour he was sent home despite me being told I was going to the delivery suite an hour earlier at 7pm. I was distressed and in a lot of pain.  
A midwife came and took the gas and air off me and my mobile phone that I was using to communicate with my partner and told me to go to sleep even tho I was in full labour. I don't know how long it was before another midwife came to check me and gave me back my pain relief.  
I texted my partner at 1am to tell him I was going to delivery. At 5am I was finally moved to delivery. I'm not sure what drips were attached me, neither is my partner as he was not present. I know I had gas and air and diamorphine as pain relief. I think I got pitocin as my contractions were stopping and starting. I was then given Remifentanil, which I did consent to as I was in so much pain.  
I had been pushing for 2 hours. Baby's head was in an awkward position plus he was large, so a decision was made to use forceps. They injected the perineum with anaesthetic and immediately cut me, but the area was not numb. Then brought the forceps in.  
I was held down in the bed as the pain was unbearable. I'm not sure if this is a correct procedure or should this have been done in theatre with appropriate pain relief? There was no immediate danger to baby or myself as far I was aware.  
After giving birth my contractions stopped and I had a retained placenta which needed to be removed in surgery. I then got a spinal block and ended up numb from the chest down.  
When I returned from surgery I was cleaned, dressed and sent to postnatal less than an hour after. My partner wasn't allowed in. I was still numb and didn't have the correct care. I remember my baby crying and I reached over to bring him to me to soothe him as I couldn't take it any longer. I dread to think what could have happened if I dropped him or fell out of the bed with him.  
I was discharged the next afternoon with little information on aftercare and zero information on what happened in surgery. Aftercare was virtually non-existent. I suffered with postnatal depression after giving birth and needed counselling.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Rosesareblue
title: Bitten by a dog
body: Was bitten by a dog on my hand. The team that treated me was excellent.

readBy.name: Tameside and Glossop Integrated Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: lovepf97
title: Dedication of all staff
body: My experience of N. Devon hospital was good. I was admitted following problems with being sick several times a day! I had a hernia which was impacting on my bowel and consider myself very lucky to being dealt with what with the problems with Covid. I was chuffed at the dedication of all the staff that I saw and have nothing but praise for all the hard work. The food was good, eye shades would have been useful at night to shade the lights either bought by the patient or the hospital?

readBy.name: Royal Devon University Healthcare NHS Foundation Trust

author: orangeye39
title: Very good services
body:
NHS are keen on medication and group therapy for treating mental health.  
If I miss an appointment C.M.H.T are quick to act by calling at my door.  
Care - services for my dying relatives were very good also.  
I must say I wanted a long tome for some tests and to get treatment but an emergency operation was very efficient. Thanks NHS staff!

author: nuthatchze79
title: Certified legend
body: I am clean and happy! My key worker Aaron is 100% certified legend - one conversation hes had with me has made me want to better my life and be a key worker one day.

author: leopardzj33
title: Great care
body: Great care from nurses attentive & very caring. Did wonderful job on my leg over period of a week.

author: ServiceUser01
title: Employment Support
body:
I began working with Raveena through the Newark Northgate site in 2020. At the time we identified that my employment in night work was one of the primary barriers to my continued recovery and concluded that I must secure better working hours in order to progress.  
Throughout the pandemic and indeed in its aftermath, Raveena was a constant source of support and encouragement. I feel her help was invaluable to me in terms of staying focused upon the small manageable goals I needed to achieve in order to prepare for and secure a new and better source of employment.  
I did eventually manage to change jobs and in addition laid out a framework for the coming years and my plans of retraining as an English language teacher with Raveena's help. She is an incredibly kind, patient and compassionate person and her presence as a source of encouragement and support in this very difficult time allowed me to use the pandemic as an opportunity to grow and consolidate my progress towards strong mental health.

author: squatcq79
title: Success of nhs
body: I have had the care of many different consultants neurology cardiology endocrinogy general surgery and opthalmology.Doctors nurses physiotherapist have been excellent in providing care enabling me to remain in good health I cannot thank them enough for my care.

author: Ian's Mrs
title: Appalling care
body:
My husband was unfortunate enough to have 2 bites of the cherry and experience very poor events at D11 Queens Medical in Nottingham. During his first visit his trainers were stolen and on the second all of his belongings including his wash bag went missing!!  
From our experience the care he received was appalling. He was left filthy, unkempt, in dirty mitts, had infection after infection. Little to no mouthcare, no soft sides on his bed despite him wriggling around due to a brain injury so he sustained extra injuries.  
We found the lack of information or concern from staff was diabolical and the farce of obtaining updates or trying to FaceTime was nothing short of disgraceful. A long list of complaints was raised through the PALS service, generic sorry this happened and we've learnt from it response.

author: marsfw49
title: Phenomenal Stroke Team
body:
We've got nothing but praise for the whole team - it's just amazing. The timescale between discharge from hospital to the Community Stroke Team ringing was outstanding and they have made a huge difference.
Most of our visits were from Jayne and we really miss her. She is relaxed, friendly, firm but fair and gives wonderful advice. So pleasant and always professional. If she was going to be late she would always ring. She has made so much difference.
His mobility has improved tremendously thanks to Jayne. He calls her his mate. 
One example was that she was recommending a walking stick but he didn't want that because it made him feel old. So she suggested a walking pole and now he goes up and down the village on his own and is fine.
Jayne is top notch, first class.

author: bumbabumba88
title: Gender clinic staff
body:
Very poor shambles of a service, if you are transgender and have Autism it seems impossible to get treatment in Leeds. Instead as a transgender Autistic patient I was discharged for a period of 6 months from the gender service, it felt like this was as time on the naughty step for having a meltdown after being overwhelmed with information. They wont sit down and speak to me to make reasonable adjustments to help you with my care. It seems this is only ever done to Autistic patients, they then ask the patient's doctor to rerefer them after 6 months, only to go back on a 3/4 year waiting list to be seen.  
In the letter it says that to get any care in future the patient must never become overwhelmed with information, complain or have a meltdown. I feel threatening and bullied because of having Autism. It feels like they are oblivious to disabilities. Trying to get an autistic person to make a promise for their autism never to effect them again. It makes me feel like nothing better than dirt on their shoes.

author: Guthrie
title: High praise for staff members
body:
Id like to firstly commend Nurse Nicola for her professionalism. I had an infected gallbladder. I became ill with sepsis and became a bit delirious to say the least. I think I was out of order to Nicola and I apologise profusely. She remained professional as I struggled with infection. You don't deserve this in your place of work how you still continued your care of me during my stay needs rewarded. I apologise. Thank You again Nicola your a Diamond.  
Also when I was suffering from Sepsis on Nightshift at the beginning of May id like to commend Nurse Chelsea who was tasked with caring for me on an hourly check basis by her actions and consistent care I am here today. She was friendly, tentative, thorough and very comforting and considerate when I was in a bit of a state due to my sepsis. Id like to thank these nurses and Nicola and Chelsea for their experience and skills which were vital and kindness when I was being diffucult as a patient especially in Nicolas case. I hope both these nurses accept my wholehearted apologies as I'm embarrassed of my actions I remember both nurses actions as difficult as I was being they remained professional.  
Chelsea you guided me through that night with so much care and consideration I thank you from the bottom of my heart.  
I was weak and you provided care to get me through what was a frightening night I appreciate all you did for me.  
Nicola. I was a pain in the **** and rabbling whilst being delirious and you being the ward nurse you always had an ear for me. Even when I was a bit off the scale I tried telling you but you knew I was off it as I was unaware at the time I was talking nonsense I thank you for being strong as a nurse and allowing me to vent whilst being a fantastic nurse too.  
Nicola I thank you for everything especially your professionalism at a time when I wasn't in a right frame of mind.  
Both of you ladies were a credit to Hairmyres Ward 4 staff who were all fantastic but both you ladies played a big part in getting me better and I thank you from the bottom of my heart.  
Please can these terrific nurses please be informed of my praise please?

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: It’s very hard passing the time in here
body: I’ve been in the hospital since April after I had a heart attack, I have been waiting on an operation for six weeks and still haven’t received it as it keeps getting cancelled or delayed. Which is really annoying as I have been ready for it for a while now. It’s very hard passing the time in here, I often find myself very bored with nothing to do. It’s not too bad now that some of the visiting is allowed, but it’s still very limited which I think should be improved. Other than that the nurses on this ward have been proving good care to me, the food is okay I’ve got very sick of it, although I never find myself going hungry.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: You can tell they love their jobs
body:
Accident and emergency was fine, it was quick and efficient. I was glad I was not sitting about long, we were admitted quickly.  
The staff there were all lovely, I had no problems with them. They seemed happy to help me, they were quick in letting me know what was going on and what was wrong.  
After coming up to daisy ward it is lovely and is a very good set up. The food is decent, my daughter is eating some and she is a picky eater. Up here has a brilliant level of care.  
The staff are all lovely, they are so helpful also. You can tell they love their jobs and they would go out of their way for you. The nurse last night, Noelle, was outstanding for me.  
The only thing I would like changed is the covid rule in place with only one parent in, I would like to spend time as a family as we have been in here a few days.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: elephantxj78
title: Small procedure
body: Had a small lump removed from shoulder , didn’t wait long and it was don under local ansthectic (wrong spelling) and was done in about 1/2 all in wasn’t nervous but was made to feel at ease right away, explained procedure before starting and gave leaflets on what to do afterwards .

author: Chillsy
title: A biopsy
body: My bi opsy was to remove a lump on my head. I was scared but the team that looked after me where fantastic

author: Shagq75
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Mixed level of care
body:
I have to say accident and emergency was a mess. My son was vomiting and the nurse told me we were a priority. I was getting frustrated as children were getting seen to and let home who had sprains, I know they are doing their best but all the rest got home and we were admitted. I feel bad complaining as I know they are doing their best. I felt like they did not want to see us or that I was a burden there. It also annoyed me that it took 3 hours for anyone to take his temperature or even offer calpol. The level of care was okay.  
Daisy ward is excellent total contrast to accident and emergency. The level of care is brilliant, they are all on top of it. It is amazing up here.  
The staff I could not fault them, they are all brilliant. The staff member Caroline is outstanding I have to say.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Spiersy
title: Mater Emergency  Department
body:
My 87 year old father was sent up by his GP with cardiac symptoms. He was seen in the clinical area but returned to the main reception were he sat for a total of 13 hours. The seats were uncomfortable. There was no information regarding food . He hadn’t eaten until I arrived after 8 hours. The single toilet was soiled with 3 different types of bodily fluids. This presented an infection prevention control and safety issue. This happened twice. Although the domestic services were called twice, there were significant periods in between. My father who has mobility issues was advised to leave the reception area, take a lift up 2 levels , follow an atrium, descend a level to use alternative toilets. He couldn’t use the lift or wait that long. He used the soiled toilet. By this stage some of the wet liquid on the floor had dried in but I was afraid he would slip and fall.  
Some suggestions:  
Domestic services available immediately in ED.  
More than one toilet  
More comfortable chairs - with arms- the number of elderly patients struggling to get up was of concern.  
Enquiring of patients in reception if they are accompanied and how to get food  
Positive feedback for the nursing and medical staff though. Fully acknowledging service pressures on ED.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

title: Waste of time
body:
Following my referral to the Sheffield IAPT service it took as long as 6 months before I was offered an appointment with a clinical psychologist.
The first session with a male clinical psychologist was dreadful. He was late. He did not apologise. He came across as arrogant, disinterested, dismissive and judgemental. His tone was uncaring. He kept interrupting me. He made little eye contact. He mostly spoke about himself, his PhD and his research most of the time, including an apparent TV appearance. He was very scruffy and unkempt in appearance. Although he was late, he ended the session early. He glossed over the risk assessment. To my shock, he informed me at the end of the first appointment that he did not think he could help me, and, against my wishes, discharged me, even though I disclosed to him I was feeling suicidal. I was left feeling completely disillusioned, demoralised and abandoned by the Shefield IAPT service. 
After this awful session I contacted Sheffield IAPT admin and asked to be reassigned to another clinician. They refused to do so, saying I had been discharged. When I appropriately challenged this, to my shock and dismay, they just hung up on me. 
I will never again contact Sheffield IAPT. It made me feel worse. I would not recommend Sheffield IAPT to anyone. It makes you feel even worse than when you started.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust

author: Eli1987
title: No admission beds, no crisis team and family told to look after him.
body:
My brother has very serious very long term mental health and he lives on his own so no one else there to look out for him. Neighbour contacted GP who contacted myself as next of kin but I don't live in London. GP felt he needed assessment for admission he has been sectioned many times before. he has a mental health team but family have no contact and the GP said they haven't been contacted him for over 2 yrs even when my brother had been in hospital. I come to London find my brother living in terrible conditions really bad and I call the crisis team because we have no idea how to contact community team. I asked if he was under a team they refused to say - my brother was standing next to me said it was OK to ask but he doesn't like the phone and he is now very paranoid and clearly needs help beyond a GP. Was told nothing could do and put phone down on me.  
There is a really good post on here already from others told exactly the same as we have been told.  
I cant stay in London because I have a job and live in another city and also have responsibilities and I am not my brothers carer because I spent 12 years before doing almost all the care. because even then this mental health NHS trust was terrible. I had to give up my university place because there was no carer support then like now. Called crisis line again and was told because I was there they wouldn't come out and assess. Didn't care I was only there for a few days didn't care GP really worried told me to call them when I was leaving .  
This hospital is paid a lot of money to provide care and they are not doing it at all as far as i can tell. To tell families that we have to look after our loved ones is a pattern for so long and it is their job. Families have to give up their lives because of these people and it is the NHS and they should be doing the job paid for. They couldn't even be bothered to come out and assess when I could give access. They hadn't bothered to try contact him at all and gave no thought to how they would do so once I had gone home. In the end he went missing and 3 weks later we were contacted by a London hospital treating him because he had collapsed. These mental health people really dont care. Why isn't someone checking on them. My brother deserves better than these people. Community team awol all during this.

author: Infantdevlin
title: Transport for EEG for infant son
body: NISTAR provided a nurse led ambulance for the transport of our 7 day old son for an EEG scan in the Royal Belfast. NISTAR provided a first class service and both nurse Natasha and driver Paddy really helped to put mummy and son at ease in what could have a stressful trip.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: Abisz74
authorRole: a staff member posting for a carer/relative
title: Care from Urgent Community Response Mid Hampshire
body:
We were really grateful for the support we received from the Team which visited us. Everyone was helpful and cheerful and it was good to know that someone had us in sight. My husband did not want to go to hospital and so from that point of view all was good and he remained at home. About two years ago he had a similar illness and was taken into hospital, (for well over a week from memory).  
The things which we found difficult were:  
He felt overwhelmed when the team came in two’s and threes, although understanding that perhaps some of this was due to training, two or three strangers standing in your small room when you are feeling ill and uncertain is a strain.  
He felt intimidated when they came and stood over him – it was better when they spoke to him at his sitting level, e.g. some people knelt in front of him  
He found it difficult to hear through the masks, especially those people who spoke quickly and/or used ‘NHS jargon or abbreviations’. Even if he could hear he found the use of professional terms difficult as he was a little confused during some of the visits  
On practical help, the continence help came too late – it would have made life easier if we had been given that earlier in his illness, I have lost track of time but I think that Allison introduced us to it towards the end of May and he had already been ill for a fortnight by then, and I was exhausted by his broken nights and constant lavatory needs.  
I experienced the strain of trying to care for him on my own, being on my own I found that by the time I had washed and dressed him it was nearly lunch time, by the time I had given him breakfast it was moving to late afternoon and so lunchtime moved to late afternoon early evening and quite often the last meal was missed. Toilet breaks and visits from your team made meal times even more haphazard and I couldn’t seem to get that under control at all. I was very worried that I seemed unable to feed him properly, especially as he is diabetic.  
I think the last visit to us from your team was over two weeks ago (from memory), since then we have not been contacted by a community nurse or by a physiotherapist, both were mentioned to us as being ‘ordered’ for us. So we have gone from daily visits to feeling alone with no contact with anyone in NHS although we have a phone number to ring so we realise we could have support if we had a pressing problem.  
He is much better now, he is able to wash his ‘top half’, he got some of his own breakfast this morning and he has managed to take a short walk outside the house. We would be grateful if you could pass on our thanks for all the care we had.

readBy.name: Southern Health Mid & North Hampshire Division

author: Weeberry57
title: I want to give other patients hope if they have the fear
body: I would like to thank the staff in the Endoscopy unit In VHK for their compassion and kindness given to me. I was given an appointment for a gastroscope which I about cancelled due to my fear of gagging on the scope. I spoke with nurse Wilma who checklisted me she gave me reassurance I would receive all the support I needed from The consultant Mr Robertson, Jean, Claire in the room, recovery nurse and Lynne from Decontamination who explained a gastroscope to me. I have to say I never felt a thing I was given throat spray and opted for the sedation (not always suitable for everyone) I woke up in recovery to a very nice nurse asking if I was alright while she went over the procedure results. I was given tea and toast and my partner picked me up. I write this to give other patients hope if they have the fear like I did. Thankyou

author: Mungo At The Crossroads
title: Mental Health Assessment Irwell Unit
body:
I had a mental health assessment on a Saturday. I was surprised to be offered an assessment as have been refused help for so long. It took place at the Irwell unit at Fairfield General Hospital.  
When I arrived there was no reception and no member of staff to report to. Just a locked ward so I couldn't even tell anyone I had arrived. Eventually I saw someone and asked them to pass on the message.  
A female nurse showed me into room. Inside was a male wearing jogging bottoms and slippers. He seemed agitated and was showing loudly about being a witness. He didn't introduce himself and he wasn't wearing a staff lanyard. No uniform. I felt he was a patient.  
He sat in the entire assessment which i found disturbing because he didn't seem professional and his demeanor was odd. The assessment was very stressful. I was asked a lot of personal questions whilst the nurse typed the answers. She was hostile and it felt like a police interview as a suspect. I was given no time to answer or formulate my thoughts. I have autism and ADHD and struggle with communication. It was quickfire questions jumping from one subject to the next. No compassion or sensitivity. One minute asked about abuse the next whether I lived in a house. If I found something upsetting there was no acknowledgement just cold, clinical and unfeeling.  
A one point I asked the man in the room his role but he failed to respond.  
After she had finished the nurse asked my consent to send the report to other professionals. I asked her if I will I get a copy? She said -no' I would have to make a subject access request. I said -in that that case no. How do I consent to something I havent seen myself?  
She told me they would not be offering a service and suggested I buy my own care.  
Afterwards I phoned up to ask who the man in the room was who declared he was a witness and was very adversarial. She just gave a first name. I asked why he wasn't wearing a uniform or lanyard. She replied he was too hot to wear a uniform. I asked if he were a patient and she replied I am terminating the call and promptly hung up on me. Refused access to mental health help.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)

author: Monmouth man
title: This mental health service is unprofessional -NHS at it's very worst
body:
This Trust is so poor in all it does. My sister has schizophrenia. She is supposedly under a community team in Camden and has been for years. They fail to make appointments . They refuse to send letters but she doesn't have a phone and quite rightly doesn't answer the door to unexpected callers as it is unsafe to do so and then they complain they cant get to see her. During covid they left her for 5 months without any contact and she was found in a terrible state by emergency council plumbers. No food, no heat, no money in the meter as her benefits had been cut off. I was told they were 'looking out for her' when I called because we couldn't visit. She was neglected and really unwell.  
The GP tries very hard but says they don't tell him when she is admitted or discharged form wards where she ends up because no one has cared. No point ever ringing that crisis line as no one there seems to know what they are doing they don't take messages for the team she is meant to be under they refused to ask the council to check on her and said they could send police . Which would just terrify her like it does everyone they do that to. All we wanted to make sure she was ok then and since then after she has been home she hasn't been for her monthly injection. I know confidentiality is very important but it is used to try shut up carers and family way too many times for her team are very quick to ring us if she needs admission and there are no beds and they want us to stop everything and look after her. Which if her community team were doing their jobs in the first place she wouldn't need. Why does no one check up on this Trust?  
She wont go and get help so is easy to just ignore it seems and the crisis line are always so obstructive they never think of safeguarding responsibility I think their only role is to gatekeep the hospital beds . Not joined up is understatement of the decade they cant even manage very basic communication like writing your patient a letter with an appointment. Apparently too hard to do so they can then say she didnt open the door to the complete stranger from the community team

readBy.name: Camden and Islington NHS Foundation Trust

author: Thank Morgmorg
title: Help from Debs at IPS Futures
body:
I was referred by my mental health worker who was my 3rd at Manor. I was not sure about if I could work and struggled to be positive about my future. I suffer from Bi Polar and not everyone understands being manic or so low you wish you did not exist. I also was concerned like my workers, Debs would just leave. This did not happen, we worked together for a year.  
I can't remember how many jobs I applied to, but Debs was there from application to interview, she once took me on a jobs thing. Debs took me and printed off my cv to take and we went to the jobs thing in Notts. I got a offered 2 jobs and at first got a bit scared as I thought I could not do it as one had some stuff I could not do, Debs spoke with the employer and arranged a training course which helped with my computer work.  
Thanks to her I can do this story as before computers were a mystery and although its a while ago I worked with her I think of her often as things changed within me, my confidence got so much better and my skills. I have not had a single day off since April 2021 when I started, where as before in other jobs my bi polar won.  
Thanks Debs for taking the time to really listen and persevere will telling me how good I could be in work. Also got a relationship and now having a baby I know thats not related to work but it is as met my partner there and never pictured myself as a mum so my thanks for all of it and sorry it took me a while to write this. I am so happy and you gave me a dream I did not know I could have,

author: lionbw98
title: Memory assessment
body:
I was worried about my memory and asked to be referred to the Memory Clinic. I was pleased that my request was taken seriously and a referral was made in a relatively short time. I live in the Ayrshire and Arran Health Board area.  
A CPN from the Elderly Community Health Care Team, visited and then referred me to the Older Adult Psychology Team  
I was seen quickly and a series of appointments made to assess me.  
Again I was pleased to be taken seriously and dealt with very respectfully.  
The whole experience was a good one and I feel much better for having gone through it.  
I am very impressed by the service I received and want the professionals involved to know how helpful it has been.  
I have been told that there is only four psychologists for the whole of South Ayrshire which, I believe, has a very high percentage of elderly residents. This makes my treatment all the more outstandingly good.

author: Emmgh49
title: My son feels really safe here
body: The GP advised me to take my son over to the hospital yesterday, we received some scans in the emergency department and didn’t wait too long to be spoken to by a doctor. The staff in ED were very helpful and were really caring towards my son. We have stayed a night in blossom, it’s really lovely. The rooms are great and there’s a lot of room for the both of us. My son feels really safe and comfortable here and all the staff have been providing the best care.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: nuthatchze79
title: Creative writing group is great
body: Creative writing group is great - team work - new skills and a great leader Kirsty made me feel competent and built confidence 10/10.

author: Melanie19
title: Caring and kind staff of the emergency medical team
body:
My husband was referred by his GP to the emergency medical team at Stoke Mandeville due to severely low sodium and potassium levels.  
The care he received from all personnel was outstanding particularly the nursing team who were so caring when he felt at his lowest and most vulnerable. You cannot overestimate the importance of caring and kind staff.  
It’s not our experience everywhere but this team at Stoke Mandeville are wonderful, Rachel, Ben and everyone.

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: It can get a bit boring
body:
I was admitted to the hospital via an ambulance. It took around an hour to come, and the staff were amazing.  
Thankfully when I arrived to the emergency department there wasn’t much people, so I didn’t have to wait very long from what I can remember. The ward has been okay, it can just get very boring when you’re sitting in same place all day. Although I’m able to watch the tv so it makes it a bit easier.  
The food from the canteens been okay. Today I ordered a tuna salad and it was very tasty.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: scorecardcb85
title: Invaluable knowledge
body: I've just got back from spending the day at Fort Victoria. I was gently encouraged to show up at the hub and go fishing and have a barbecue in the west Wight, organised by Tony from Inclusion. It was an awesome day out. The human connection/ interaction I have gained from services has been an absolute lifeline back into 'normal' society. I spent some of the day talking with Kirstie about recovery and mental health, which I found invaluable. If you are prepared to engage with services, there is a lot of positive experiences to be had.

author: mrob22
title: Endometriosis & Fertility
body: After 6 GP appointments over 6 years where my terrible period-related symptoms were dismissed as normal and being prescribed a whole spectrum of painkillers, anti inflammatories and other meds, I finally decided to trust my gut and book a private consultation with a gynaecologist to confirm there was nothing to worry about. As soon as I listed my symptoms, the consultant said it sounded like textbook endometriosis and carried out a trans-vaginal ultrasound to confirm stage 4 deep infiltrating disease including a large 10cm cyst on an ovary and significant bowel involvement. They were absolutely shocked I hadn't been sent for any tests with the symptoms I was presenting with. They were also shocked that a large node of disease on my vaginal wall was missed during a colposcopy about 3 months before. I was so upset that after so many appointments and chances for tests to be carried out, I now had disease that had progressed so far, causing damage to many organs and potentially impacting my fertility. I was referred back to the NHS as my case is too complicated to be treated at a private hospital and will require a multidisciplinary team at the Endometriosis Centre at the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital. Since being referred back to the NHS, I have had various tests including an anti-Mullerian hormone test to give a rough indication of egg reserve as fertility can be significantly impacted by Endometriosis. As I was found to have a low reading, I was referred to the Assisted Contraception Service in Glasgow to explore my options before surgery which would cause trauma to the ovaries and therefore further reduce my egg reserve. I was told at the Endometriosis centre that since October 2021, Endometriosis is now funded by the NHS for fertility treatment. However, when I had my consultation they told me that I wouldn't qualify for funding as I won't be losing my ovaries during my surgery. They said they can put my case forward to a panel to take into account my low AMH reading but couldn't guarantee I would be accepted. I found out a week later that I wasn't accepted which was very disheartening as it showed that Endometriosis is still not properly understood by medical professionals in adjacent fields. I am now back to awaiting laparoscopic surgery for my stage 4 disease, but all surgeries at the Endometriosis Centre at the Queen Elizabeth have been off since mid-September 2022, meaning no treatment for anyone of their waiting list for almost 9 months. This is due to overspill of hospital inhabitants into gynaecology as it is seen as 'benign' and 'routine' when the symptoms of Endometriosis are severe and life-limiting. It's very unfortunate that women's health gets such little acknowledgement, research and funding, which is now leading to extreme backlogs and suffering that didn't need to happen. As a disease that is as common as diabetes and asthma in women (1 in 10), it is shocking how unknown/misunderstood it is amongst GPs, nurses, and incredibly, apparently gynaecologists too, with widespread misinformation. This needs to change and more emphasis needs to be placed on this condition that impacts so heavily on everyday life, and sadly, fertility too.

author: branxm55
title: Excellent service
body: Everybody was professional but friendly. I felt very at ease while having a procedure.

author: handsetmr97
title: Learning life skills
body:
I have been a patient in Arnold Lodge for just over 3 months I have enjoyed using the gym and shop and library and education. I engage in the problem solving group also I go into ward round every 2 weeks I feel involved in my care and treatment and feel listened to I have settled in well and am learning life skills from structured day, education, cooking and staff who; help me to handle situations better in positive way. My side room is a really nice comfortable place to be.  
My room is very open window and the light shines in I have a carpet and a bed a desk a decent chair also a full length body + face mirror the best feature of the room. I like the privacy door so that the body is respected and dignified in my previous placement as a patient they would look through a panel/window and get full body shot no mattes if I am on a full level or a non self harmer I got used to it but now I can have a shower in peace (lol).  
Outside my window is the gardens allotments lots of trees and a foot path to walk along in a group walk if the staff aren't busy. The staff gave me everything I needed until my first shop day also I was pleased very pleased with the standard, presentation and taste of the patient menu my best meal is avocado, tomato pasta salad and a jacket potato + cheese I feel well here hope to continue to progress through therapy and hope to progress to next step.

author: Club33
title: Care and compassion at the TIA Clinic
body:
I attended the TIA Clinic this week. Nurse Amanda called me in at my appointed time, checked my blood pressure, and weight, and monitored my heart rate. She was lovely and cheerful and put me very much at ease.  
I was then seen by Dr Mukhtar, who was assisted by Nurse Valerie. Dr Mukhtar, who was an absolute gentleman, requested further tests and Valerie ensured that I got an appointment to attend Radiology later in the day for a doppler test and brain scan which was marvellous as she made me feel that I was being completely cared for in one fell swoop without the anxiety of having to return for the scans at a later date - thank you Valerie!  
I can't emphasise enough how grateful I am for the care and compassion shown to me by this TIA team and how considerate they were to me throughout.  
Thank you Dr Mukhtar, and Nurses Valerie and Amanda!

readBy.name: Western Health and Social Care Trust

author: Middleagedlady
title: A positive experience at Grantham's Tower Block, Women's services
body:
I was invited to attend a fast track gynae appointment this month.  
I was nervous and keen to get the appointment over with.  
I was met by the friendliest ladies at the front door, and then a very warm and chatty nurse, who weighed and measured me before I was called in to the clinical room to see the specialist.  
Again, I was made to feel welcome by friendly nurses who radiated kindness. I was then introduced to the specialist who explained the results of my scan, explained clearly what the next step would be and how this would take place. Everything was explained and I was asked if I was ok after the examination, offered a drink and encouraged at every step. I even had my hand held.  
It was a good outcome and I was left encouraged that my condition could be alleviated with a simple medication, that would transform my symptoms.  
I left thanking God for the NHS and the committed and wonderful staff who serve us. Thank you

author: vikkilan
title: Care received when my daughter broke her arm
body:
Extremely frustrated, angry and shocked at the level of care.  
My young daughter fell off a table and fractured her radius. My mum who is a nurse was on holiday and I phoned her, sending her pics of the injury. She immediately said it didn't look good and agreed with me to contact the doctor. I called 111 at 18.45 explaining the situation and a doctor called me back at 20.30. The doctor asked me some questions and said she needed to be seen and told me to take her to A/E for a 21.30 paediatric appointment. I duly did so and on arrival the receptionist said that I shouldn't have been told that, paediatrics is closed. (I stay in Crosshouse and could have been there within a few minutes). I was told to go to the waiting room.  
For almost the entire 2 hours I was waiting for triage my wee one cried continuously, letting her arm hang down and clearly very distressed with pain. In fact I could hear people discussing my situation saying things like this is terrible, just awful, how can they leave that child like this. One person came up to me and asked if there was anything they could do to help. Several people left the department and I heard someone say, Ive no chance if they can leave a wean like that.  
At 21.30 I was called for my child to be triaged, and it was this experience that has left me feeling frustrated, angry and shocked.  
I spoke to the nurse saying I had followed all guidelines by calling 111 etc knowing how stretched the NHS is at present, and was given an appointment for 21.30 but had to wait 2 hours for her to be seen, and asked if she shouldn't have been seen sooner. The nurse told me that it didnt work that way and that she had to wait like everyone else, then started telling me about chest pains and much worse injuries that takes priority, and in what I felt was a very patronising manner. I then told the nurse that despite my daughter being in pain or discomfort she wouldn't take medicine orally and had never been able to do so, to which the staff member replied well she'll just need to, because she will be out there for 5/6 hours. (She had scarlet fever a few years back and the GP stopped the antibiotics because of the trauma it caused her having to to take them).  
I looked at her in disbelief at being told that a very distressed, and clearly in severe pain, young child could be expected to wait 6 hours to be seen. I think I said something like You're joking, shes in pain!, to which I was told shes moving it around fine!  
I then told the nurse that I had no choice but to complain about this whole scenario to which they asked if I was going to complain about them?  
I then attempted to discuss the implications of a 6 hour wait with a distressed child and asked if I should take her home and return tomorrow. I was told that was up to me what you do, you put the pieces together and make the choice, but she will just have to wait again in the morning like everyone else.  
At this point I was really frustrated, my child was sobbing and exhausted and I was in a complete dilemma as to whether I should stay or return in the morning. I have no medical experience but remembering that my mother believed from the pics it was likely to be broken and the doctor telling me she needed seen that night, I then said to the nurse that I was frightened that if I took her home, and she has a broken bone she could do further damage to it. In what I felt was a very condescending manner the staff member replied Damage? what damage could she do?  
I got up and left.  
The next day, a full 16 hours later, my daughter was diagnosed with a fractured radius.  
I fully understand that the NHS have huge problems, I fully understand that long waits in A/E are the norm, and I fully understand that mistakes like getting a paediatric appointment that doesn't exist can happen, but what I will never, EVER, understand is how a very distressed young child (and her mother) can be treated so condescendingly, with such coldness, and a complete lack of empathy and care, from the caring profession.  
I would like to finish by asking;-  
(a) Would it have been out with the realms of procedure for my child to be given a paediatric pain relieving patch or even an anti-inflammatory gel given that the waiting time was around 6 hours?  
(b) Why was my child vital signs not taken and recorded, especially her pulse with what was very clearly an injured arm?

author: lepusqr45
title: Severe neck pain caused by osteoarthritis
body:
I was referred to trust physio, Seana  
The first contact was a phone call during which I found Seana very  
empathetic and understanding of the amount of pain I was in and the impact  
it was having on my quality of life.  
The phone calls continued on a 2 weekly basis and I took on board and put  
into practice the excellent advice given to me.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Emmgh49
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Staff providing the best care
body: I’ve been on this ward for 12 days due to an infection. The staff have all been providing great care to me. They are all very friendly and chat away which is good. I think the idea of having a toilet in the bay instead of having 4 patients is great, as it does feel a bit stuffy at times with four patients. Having three to a bay would be much better. The toilet would be good because there’s usually people using the toilet and I have to wait longer. Therefore if three people use it there will be less waiting time.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: cheetahkj98
title: Consultation at fertility clinic
body:
I attended the regional fertility clinic a few months a go, I felt the consultation was completely inadequate. I was diagnosed with PCOS in the appointment and it was just as if they were reading from a script. I was not given any information on PCOS, all I was told is that it is very common and to lose weight. I left the clinic in tears as I felt I had been waiting on that appointment for a while and i was walking away so disappointed. There was no support or advice on how to try and conceive naturally or what I could do between the appointment and my review just to go away and lose weight to be able to get on the waiting list.  
I feel that doctors need to be more empathetic.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust

author: jupiterrp74
title: I was not impressed
body: I tested + for C19 last year in hospital. I stayed in hospital while I was treated and felt harassed and harangued by the contact tracing service six or seven times a day, despite being too ill to speak on the phone. Needless to say I was not impressed.

author: Andy129
title: Positive feedback cleaning staff.
body: In early June 2022 I sadly had to visit A&E at the George Elliot Hospital in Nuneaton for a medical emergency. I turned up at 6.30am and after being booked in, quietly watch two staff members furiously cleaning the department. What struck me was how thorough these two ladies were, cleaning above door frames, inside door jams and walls. Hugely reassuring to know Tilly & Sharon were so professional and thorough so for me as a patient it was very reassuring to know how clean this department was being kept. Marvellous and thanks should be extended to these staff for how dedicated they were.

author: tangocf79
title: Lagan Valley Phone First ED
body:
More exceptional care from LV Phone First ED Dept. I have had a previous and extremely positive experience and yet again, the high quality and personalised care provided by the amazing staff shone through.  
Following a hand injury at the gym, I phoned at 8am, offered an appointment at 8:30, triaged immediately, assessed by Nurse Practitioner Audrey with x-ray complete by 8:45!  
I was splinted and provided with an appointment at the Hand Clinic in the Ulster and was quickly in my way.  
As I was going on holiday, the Hand clinic appointment was for 2 weeks time (usually one week). Lisa who was a member of the Admin team, kindly checked on the system for a cancellation at said clinic for the next day. Unfortunately the clinic was fully booked however she remained persistent and thoughtfully tried to contact them directly. Again to no avail with Lisa stating that she would keep trying throughout the day.  
I was delighted when Lisa’s colleague Valerie contacted me at 2pm to offer me an appointment at the Hand Clinic due to a cancellation.  
I am so very very grateful to everyone but particularly Lisa and Valerie who were tenacious, determined, thoughtful and kind and who went that extra mile for me.  
Thank you lovely ladies, you are an asset to the department and patients like myself.  
PS I love this service and I hope it is seen as the gold standard and replicated in other Trusts.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: camelopardalisew73
title: Kind, reassuring and caring staff
body:
Today I had a flexible sigmoidoscopy at Treliske Hospital.  
I'd just like to say how kind, reassuring and caring every member of staff I encountered were, which must have been about 8 or 9 people altogether. they all introduced themselves, they all explained exactly what was going to happen and were very kind in the recovery room. i was lucky enough not to have a serious diagnosis, but was still treated with care.  
I cannot praise everyone enough.

title: Trusted Practice
body: I went to see a nurse to discuss my fairly newly diagnosed Diabetes. I was given time and attention and kindness. I felt relaxed and everything was discussed very thoroughly.

author: South Eastern HSC Trust
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Ulster Hospital Ward 3A
body: I have found all the members of your staff in all categories to be most efficient, professional, caring and understanding. It was worth being unwell just to see and meet so many wonderful people. My respect and love with God's blessing go with each one of you.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: South Eastern HSC Trust
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Ulster Hospital Neely Ward
body:
During my stay on the ward, overall, I had amazing care from the nursing staff and nursing assistants. Caitlyn, one of the nurses, went above and beyond regular bedside manner to help make what could have been a very difficult stay, an easier one. Nurses like Caitlyn should be celebrated and used as an example of how nurses should behave. Pauline was another nurse who massively helped during a very difficult night.  
Kerry, a nursing assistant and Janine, another nursing assistant, have the perfect personalities to raise spirits on the ward. A student nurse, Jadyn, gives me hope for the future of nursing staff. On a much more personal note, Caitlyn, in particular, really helped me cope with the emotional side of my surgery and having to stay longer in hospital than I had initially been led to believe would be happening.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: South Eastern HSC Trust
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Ulster Hospital Neely Ward
body: The staff in Neely Ward have been fantastic even though they are run off their feet - I couldn't fault them, their professionalism and friendliness. A credit to the NHS.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: tucanars36
title: Positive A&E Experience
body: I recently presented at A&E with a sudden onset headache and partial loss of vision. I was in and out in less than 3 hours. Chris, the A&E consultant was fantastic and explained everything too me, with it ultimately believed to be a migraine. Thank you for the positive experience and keeping me soo calm.

author: Wishaw123
title: Wishaw a and e staff and wait
body:
I find the attitude of reception staff at the Wishaw A&E to honestly be a joke. I asked a simple question and got a rude and abrupt answer by a receptionist, who ignored another member of public during this time.  
I found them to be rude and unapologetic. I just feel like after my 7 hour wait to see a doctor, a little common courtesy and care wouldn’t go a miss.

author: South Eastern HSC Trust
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Downe Hospital Rapid Assessment Centre
body: We were very impressed by the care and attention we received from all the staff - doctors, staff nurses and everyone we came in contact with. Also, a special thanks to the ambulance paramedics who were very efficient and helpful.

author: South Eastern HSC Trust
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Downe Hospital Ward 2
body: As an inpatient in Ward 2 I have to stay a huge thank you to all the staff for their loving care and attention. This is a wonderful hospital and without it and the wonderful staff then we would miss it so much, we appreciate everything they have done for us. Again, sincere thanks to everyone.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Ernesto
title: My wonderful therapist sessions
body:
I think we are made up of many pieces that over the years some of us leave behind, forgetting them; and as we grow we acquire more challenges, society influences our lives by pressing us and causing endless events in our body, spirit and mind. In my case, the consultation was directed in one direction, but as we went back in time, we found many pieces of me that were missing in my present, which directly affected, in addition to overthinking and stress, they were a bad combination and had repercussions. In my sexual life, during the sessions I was able to self-understand what was happening in me, but it was not so easy, since without the help of the professional Dr. Peltier-Brown she was able to guide me with effective methods to help me meet the goals that we had said to the beginning of the sessions. Now I feel different, more secure, calm and continuing to learn to know myself, enjoy and value what I have. a life full of adventures.  
Thanks Dr Peltier-Brown, I will always keep you in my heart!

author: South Eastern HSC Trust
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: Ulster Hospital Ward 5C
body: The staff have been excellent. I felt very comfortable, everyone on the ward was kind and friendly.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Shannon3x
title: My son fell
body: My 18 month old son fell and hurt his leg, I took him to A&E at Ayr hospital, the staff, Nurses & doctors were amazing and made us feel at ease
